content.html: I‚Äôve upgraded something on my computer, and now there‚Äôs a new alert noise. But it‚Äôs very soft, and peculiar, and I can‚Äôt figure it out. Maybe this is like the time there was a cockroach in a aluminium can but it sounded more like a rat in the roof. Is there a bug in my headphones?

content.html: I had a dream last night about adding a search box to the top right corner of a website. Is the universe trying to tell me something?
content.value: I had a dream last night about adding a search box to the top right corner of a website. Is the universe trying to tell me something?

content.html:
The WS Contest tool was breaking on Index pages that don‚Äôt yet have any (existing) pages. The problem was in the usage of the dflydev/dot-access-data, which is a thing for pulling values out of deep arrays. It‚Äôs sort of useful, but not widely used so does feel a bit weird. Maybe we should remove it from wikisource/api.

Actually, scratch that: I just went to look, and it‚Äôs got eighty-three million installs on Packagist. So I guess it‚Äôs more widely used than I‚Äôd thought. I‚Äôll leave it in for now.
content.value:

Maybe we should remove it from wikisource/api.
Actually, scratch that: I just went to look, and it‚Äôs got eighty-three million installs on Packagist. So I guess it‚Äôs more widely used than I‚Äôd thought. I‚Äôll leave it in for now.

content.html: Hacker News is going on about the CSS of the W3C‚Äôs homepage not working. I was worried, reading the headline, that they‚Äôd got rid of the Core Styles! But no, those are safe.
content.value: Hacker News is going on about the CSS of the W3C‚Äôs homepage not working. I was worried, reading the headline, that they‚Äôd got rid of the Core Styles! But no, those are safe.

content.html:
I‚Äôve been working on linking Commons items to Trove. It‚Äôs not complicated, on the surface, but of course once you get into it things get more annoying. I‚Äôm trying to just figure out the basics, and not get too deep into the weeds.

Basically what we want is for every file on Commons, that has been sourced from an institution that‚Äôs aggregated in Trove, to have a P10044 statement (‚ÄòTrove Work ID‚Äô), and for that to be displayed in the |source= parameter of the Information template. But we also want to say which library (etc.) it came from, and to link to that library‚Äôs catalogue (because that‚Äôs where the actual image file is stored). This means, I think, that we‚Äôll want to stick to the SLQ, SLWA, SLSA, AWM-image, etc. templates that have institution-specific information and links, and just add a simple line to those that explains that the file‚Äôs metadata is also on trove and what its ID there is.
content.value:
I‚Äôve been working on linking Commons items to Trove. It‚Äôs not complicated, on the surface, but of course once you get into it things get more annoying. I‚Äôm trying to just figure out the basics, and not get too deep into the weeds.
Basically what we want is for every file on Commons, that has been sourced from an institution that‚Äôs aggregated in Trove, to have a P10044 statement (‚ÄòTrove Work ID‚Äô), and for that to be displayed in the |source= parameter of the Information template. But we also want to say which library (etc.) it came from, and to link to that library‚Äôs catalogue (because that‚Äôs where the actual image file is stored). This means, I think, that we‚Äôll want to stick to the SLQ, SLWA, SLSA, AWM-image, etc. templates that have institution-specific information and links, and just add a simple line to those that explains that the file‚Äôs metadata is also on trove and what its ID there is.

content.html:
The Community Wishlist Survey starts today. This is an annual survey that my team at the Wikimedia Foundation runs, to figure out what we should work on for the following year. It‚Äôs always so interesting to see what features and bugs are felt to be the most important. Quite often I agree, and get excited about working on them; sometimes I‚Äôve never even heard of the software components in question! The Wikimedia universe is wide and varied.

So if anyone Wikimedians out there have ideas, please come and propose them!
content.value:
The Community Wishlist Survey starts today. This is an annual survey that my team at the Wikimedia Foundation runs, to figure out what we should work on for the following year. It‚Äôs always so interesting to see what features and bugs are felt to be the most important. Quite often I agree, and get excited about working on them; sometimes I‚Äôve never even heard of the software components in question! The Wikimedia universe is wide and varied.
So if anyone Wikimedians out there have ideas, please come and propose them!

content.html: The (fairly terrific) locator-tool now has aerial imagery available as a map layer, making geolocating photos even more fun.
content.value: The (fairly terrific) locator-tool now has aerial imagery available as a map layer, making geolocating photos even more fun.

name: Sam Wilson
note:
I‚Äôm a programmer from Fremantle, Western Australia. I work for the Wikimedia Foundation and spend my spare time working on wikis, family history, and OpenStreetMap. I try to find time for some furniture-making.
Contact me by email, or on the fediverse/Mastodon as @samwilson@wikis.world, or on Matrix as @samwilson:matrix.org.
